entries.fullText:
DOMESTIC POSTAGE.
FIRST CLASS. - Letters and all written matter, whether
sealed or unsealed, and all other matter sealed, nailed, sewed,
tied, or fastened in any manner, so that it cannot be easily examined,
two cents per ounce or fraction thereof. A special
ten-cent stamp when attached to a letter, in addition to
the lawful postage, shall entitle the letter to immediate delivery
at any place containing 4000 population or over, or within
one mile of the post-office. Postal cards, one cent each.
SECOND CLASS. - All regular newspapers, magazines,
and other periodicals issued at intervals not exceeding three
months; the postage is one cent for each four ounces,
payable by postage stamps.
THIRD CLASS. - Embraces printed books, pamphlets,
circulars, engravings, lithographs, proof-sheets and manuscript
accompanying the same, and all matter of the same general
character, and not having the character of personal correspondence.
Circulars produced by hektograph or similar process,
or by electric pen, are rated as third class. The limit of weight
for mail matter of the third class is four pounds, except in the
case of single books exceeding that weight. The rate of postage
on mail matter of the third class is one cent for each
two ounces or fraction thereof.
FOURTH CLASS. All mailable matter not included in the
three preceding classes, which is so prepared for mailing as
to be easily taken from the wrapper and examined. Rate,
one cent per ounce or fraction thereof. Limit of weight,
4 lbs. Full prepayment compulsory. Liquids, and other like
injurious matter, not admitted, except under conditions which
may be learned at any post-office.
Registry fee, ten cents, which, with the postage, must
be fully prepaid. The name and address of sender must be
given on the outside of the envelope or wrapper.
POSTAL NOTE AND MONEY ORDER FEES. - Postal notes,
3c. each, in denominations of $4.99 and less, payable to bearer.
Such notes are invalid upon the expiration of three months
from the last day of the month of issue, but the holder can
after that time get it renewed at the Department at Washington,
upon payment of a fee of 3 cents. For Money Orders in
denominations of $100 or less, the following fees are charged:
Orders not exceeding $5, 5c.; over $5 to $10, 8 c.; $10 to $15,
10 c.; $15 to $30, 15 c.; $30 to $40, 20 c.; $40 to $50, 25 c.; $50
to $60, 30 c.; $60 to $70, 35 c.; $70 to $80, 40 c.; $80 to $100, 45 c.
entries.summaryText: Explanation of domestic postage rates and fees for postal notes and money orders.

entries.fullText:
FOREIGN POSTAGE
The rates of postage to the countries of the Universal Postal
Union (embracing nearly every civilized country) are as
follows:
On LETTERS, five cents for each half ounce or fraction
thereof - prepayment optional. Double rates are collected
on delivery of unpaid or short-paid letters.
On newspapers, books, pamphlets, photographs, sheet music,
maps, engravings, and similar printed matter, one cent for
each two ounces or fraction thereof.
To CANADA (including Nova Scotia, New Brunswick,
Manitoba, and Prince Edward Island): LETTERS, two
cents for each ounce or fraction thereof; Books, Circulars,
and similar printed matter, one cent for each two
ounces or fraction thereof; SECOND CLASS MATTER,
same as the United States; SAMPLES OF MERCHANDISE
(no dutiable articles or articles of intrinsic value admitted)
ten cents for each package, which must not exceed 8
ounces in weight - prepayment compulsory.
To AUSTRALIA (except New South Wales, Queensland,
and Victoria), via San Francisco: ON LETTERS, five cents
for each half ounce or fraction thereof:
on NEWSPAPERS, two cents each - prepayment compulsory.

INTERNATIONAL OR FOREIGN MONEY-ORDER FEES
On Algeria, Belgium, British India, Cape Colony, Constantinople,
Dominion of Canada, Egypt, England, France, German
Empire, Hong Kong, Ireland, Italy, Jamaica, Japan,
Newfoundland, New South Wales, New Zealand, Portugal,
Sandwich Islands, Scotland, Shanghai, Sweden, Switzerland,
Tasmania, Victoria.
For sums not exceeding $10...................................................10 cents.
Over $10 and not exceeding $20..........................................20 cents.
Over $20 and not exceeding $30..........................................30 cents.
Over $30 and not exceeding $40..........................................40 cents.
Over $40 and not exceeding $50..........................................50 cents.
Orders can also be obtained on Austria and East Indies, by
remittance through the Postal Department of Switzerland,
subject to the rates of the Swiss Department to those countries.
Also on Denmark, Norway, and the Netherlands, through the
Postal Department of the German Empire, subject to the rates
of the German Department to those countries.
No order issued for a larger amount than $50 in U.S.money.
entries.summaryText: Explanation of foreign postage rates and fees for international or foreign money-order.

entries.fullText: Grandma Garfield died at the Garfield homestead at Mentor at 5 o'clock Saturday morning. Her death was like a peaceful falling to sleep. Eliza Ballou Garfield was born Sept. 25, 1802, at the foot of Mount Monadnock, New Hampshire, and married Abram Garfield, of Watertown, Mass., in 1827, coming to Orange, Cuyahoga county, O., 1834, when her eldest child, Thomas Gar-field, now of Grand Rapids, Mich, was 6 years of age. She was a woman of strong sense and spirit, and had a singular capacity for managing and educating children. Her care and energy produced one of America's greatest public men and carried the family in respectable poverty to the point where it could make its own way. James A. Garfield was her pride and joy, and she has aged very rapidly from the day that Guiteau's bullet struck him down.
entries.summaryText: Grandma Garfield died at the Garfield homestead at Mentor at 5 o'clock Saturday morning. Her death was like a peaceful falling to sleep.

entries.fullText: Left Milton Penn at 4.08.A.M. to go from Harrisburg to Phila.- arrived at 9.15 P.M. Met Lucy E. at Fosters'- talked program & union progress- & took tea & slept - Miss Morrison- she had been ill with severe cold for the two weeks since I left
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Milton, PA and traveled to Philadelphia via Harrisburg. She met with Lucy E. at Fosters' and discussed program and union progress. She also met with Miss Morrison who had been ill for two weeks.

entries.fullText: In the suit for $5,000 damages brought by Olympia Brown Willis against the election inspectors of Racine the supreme court holds that the legislature did not confer on females the same suffrage enjoyed by males, but restricted it school matters, Judgment was for defendants.

entries.fullText: MARCH, FRIDAY 16. 1888.
SATURDAY 17.
SUNDAY 18.
MARCH, MONDAY 19. 1888.
TUESDAY 20.
WEDNESDAY 21.

Action on Rev. N.M. Mann's Resignation Last Night.

The call for a special meeting of the members
of the First Unitarian Church Society
last night for the purpose of taking action on
the resignation of the pastor, brought out
very few people. It is doubtful if half the
number would have ventured out had the
business to be transacted been on less importance
to the congregation.
The meeting was called to order by Mr.
Wilder, who suggested that Justice Angle be
requested to act as chairman, and G. H.
Smith secretary. On taking the chair Justice
Angle addressed the members in a very brief
and fitting manner, as to the cause of calling
them together, and as he expressed it, a
sorrowful occasion. It brought to his mind
vividly reccollections of the past, and his
personal respect for Mr. Mann during
the long time he had officiated as pastor
of the society. In all that time
he had never known him to have aught but
the good of the society at heart, and his
teaching had always been strictly on the subject
of morality. He regretted that Mr.
Mann was compelled to ask the church to
relieve him on account of his failing health,
and hoped that whatever action was taken
on the subject of his resignation, it would be
done with the same spirit that prompted
Mr. Mann to offer it.
The letter containing the resignation was
then read. It was dated January 16, 1888,
and reviewed briefly his connection with the
church, and his final determination to unconditionally
offer his resignation to take effect
June 1st.
Some discussion was indulged in by the
gentlemen present, and it seemed to be the
desire of all to devise some plan whereby its
acceptance would not compel them to abandon
all hope of Mr. Mann's returning at the
end of a few months in a better physical condition,
and resume his pastorate without it
being necessary to issue another call to him.
Mr. Wilder was satisfied from what he could
learn from a personal interview on that point
with Mr. Mann that such conditions could never
be considered by him, for although he had
not contemplated accepting any other call,
he felt that he could never return. In view,
however, of the feelings of the members on
the subject he suggested the following resolution,
which was adopted:
Resolved. That we do accept the resignation of
Rev. Mr. Mann conditionally, hoping he will, after
a few months' rest, return here and find a warmer
welcome than anywhere else in the world.
entries.summaryText: The First Unitarian Church Society held a special meeting to discuss the resignation of Rev. N.M. Mann. The resignation was accepted conditionally, with the hope that he would return after a few months' rest.

people: J. V. Alexander and G. H. Smith
entries.fullText:
Some discussion was indulged in by the
gentlemen present, and it seemed to be the
desire of all to devise some plan whereby its
acceptance would not compel them to abandon
all hope of Mr. Mann's returning at the
end of a few months in a better physical condition,
and resume his pastorate without it
being necessary to issue another call to him.
Mr. Wilder was satisfied from what he could
learn from a personal interview on that point
with Mr. Mann that such conditions could never
be considered by him, for although he had
not contemplated accepting any other call,
he felt that he could never return. In view,
however, of the feelings of the members on
the subject he suggested the following resolution,
which was adopted:
Resolved. That we do accept the resignation of
Rev. Mr. Mann conditionally, hoping he will, after
a few months' rest, return here and find a warmer
welcome than anywhere else in the world.
The conditions are that he shall report to
the trustees of the church his ability or inability
to return in time for them to know
what the church may depend on for a pastor
after the summer vacation. During the
month of June and until the second Sunday
in July, some one will have to officiate as
pastor, and such selection as the trustees may
make will be entirely satisfactory to the
congregation. At the suggestion of Justice
Angle, the following resolution was adopted:
Resolved. That the trustees of the church be
delegated to communicate to Mr. Mann our regret
that the conditions of his health necessitates such
action, and to convey to him the assurance of the
undivided respect, esteem and love of the society
for him, and our appreciation of the manner in
which he has discharged the duties of his high
office while he was been our pastor.
The meeting then adjourned. The trustees
are J. A. Hinds, E. T. Curtis, S. Brewster,
Dr. Porter Farley, Samuel Wilder, J. V.
Alexander and G. H. Smith.
entries.summaryText: The gentlemen present discussed a plan to accept the resignation of Rev. Mr. Mann conditionally, hoping he will, after a few months' rest, return here and find a warmer welcome than anywhere else in the world.

of Rome- Sent telegram to
R. ?. Zucte? of the f? -
entries.summaryText: Met with Sister May, May Wright, and Theodore B. Sewall at Central state and gave them sleep blankets for their voyage to England on City of Rome. Sent telegram to R. ?. Zucte? of the f?.

entries.fullText:
Bought Grenadine at A. L.
Mauve & Co’s - and had it- fitted
by Mrs Nylocroues Fuller-
entries.summaryText: Bought Grenadine at A. L. Mauve & Co’s and had it fitted by Mrs Nylocroues Fuller.

entries.fullText:
The Sewalls of Indianapolis
sail today on the City of Rome
from New York - Anchor Line -
entries.summaryText: The Sewalls of Indianapolis sail today on the City of Rome from New York - Anchor Line -.

entries.fullText:
May & self called on Mrs
? Sunday evn’g -
entries.summaryText: May and Susan called on Mrs. ? on Sunday evening.

entries.fullText:
Just after breakfast - Lucy E
was lying on No. 19 lounge - when
putting her right arm down to
rise, a needle stuck into it and
broke off- & was out of sight
- at last Dr Brown & Mullegan?
both came - but failed to find
the needle - as it was left -
entries.summaryText: Lucy E accidentally got a needle stuck in her arm and Dr. Brown and Mullegan were unable to remove it.

entries.fullText:
Dress Maker -
Miss Coad - fixing
wiring old black silk-
dress-
entries.summaryText: Miss Coad worked on fixing a black silk dress.

entries.fullText:
Working on the
? report-
of V. W. L.A. for
the past four years
entries.summaryText: Susan worked on a report for the past four years of the V. W. L.A.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self and
Mrs. Norm -- Spent the
afternoon & took tea
with Maria & Libbie
Porter -- at the Farley home --
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary, Mrs. Norm, Maria, and Libbie Porter spent the afternoon and had tea at the Farley home.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary, Niece Lucy E.
and self took tea
at Mrs. Williams -- Ring
street --
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary, Niece Lucy E., and self had tea at Mrs. Williams on Ring street.

entries.fullText: Mrs. Stanton & self took 4.30 train for Byron Center - took tea at Mr. J. Peckams - spoke in Presbyterian Church to good audience & rode two miles to Mrs. Newton Greens - very warm day -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Stanton & self travel to Byron Center, speak at Presbyterian Church, and visit Mrs. Newton Greens.

entries.fullText: Spent the day at Mrs. Green's lovely farm home - some 60 or 70 women & one man called in P.M. They came from Le Naz, Batavia --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at Mrs. Green's farm home and meets with a group of women and one man from Le Naz and Batavia.

entries.fullText: Left Mrs. Greens at 8.20 - reached Buffalo 11.45 - luncheon with Julia England Johnson - Maggie Stanton there - at 2. went over to Jamestown- arrived 6.20 - & were met by Mrs. Henderson & escorted to the palatial home of Mrs Reuben E. Fenton - she has two splendid daughters, Mrs. Gilbert & Miss Sofford
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Mrs. Green's and travels to Buffalo, has lunch with Julia England Johnson and Maggie Stanton, then travels to Jamestown and is escorted to the home of Mrs. Reuben E. Fenton where she meets her daughters.

entries.fullText: A telegram to Colonel D.R. Anthony, received at 4:30 yesterday afternoon, from Mrs. Anthony, dated at Mackinaw, Michigan, bore the sad announcement of the death of their little daughter, Annette. The news was entirely unexpected, the only intimation of anything wrong being a telegram to the Colonel's son, received an hour previous, saying that the little one was very sick. No particulars as to the cause of her death were given. It was only last Monday that Mrs. Anthony and Annette left for the northern trip. Colonel Anthony leaves today for Mackinaw, to return with Mrs. Anthony and to bring the body home for burial.
entries.summaryText: Colonel D.R. Anthony's Youngest Daughter Dies Suddenly at Mackinaw.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Fenton & 8 or 10 others dined
with us at Mrs. C.W. Schofield's -
at the Sherman House - & at
2:20 we had meeting in Opera
House of a 100 hundred women - &
& 85 men house was packed -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Fenton and others dine and attend a meeting with a large crowd.

entries.fullText:
I took 8:50 train for Salamanca
& through to Rochester
arriving at 2. P.M. - to find
all - Miss Morrison, Lucy & Louise
& Sister Mary gone to the Lake -
- the weather is lovely -
& the trip has been lovely -
entries.summaryText: Susan travels to Salamanca and then Rochester to find her companions gone to the lake.

entries.fullText:
How little I knew
or felt of the agony of
Sister Annie & brother
D.R. & all during these
days - Can never
understand why not
one of them telegraphed us!!
entries.summaryText: Susan reflects on not being informed of the agony of Sister Annie and D.R. during the past few days.

entries.fullText:
The Leavenworth Times of Sat. 11th came
today & bro’t sad news of death of brother
D. R.’s little Annette - Aug. 10. she would
have been 5 yrs old Dec. 12th it is a
fearful shock - she was a very
bright & promising child - & a perfect
best of her household. poor Maude -
entries.summaryText: Susan receives sad news of the death of brother D.R.'s daughter Annette.

entries.fullText:
Brother D.R ‘s letter -
dated Monday the 12th. came
to-day - it has seemed an
age - the waiting for some
word from them direct -
his heart is crushed & the
entries.summaryText: Susan receives a letter from brother D.R. and notes his heart is crushed.

entries.fullText: AUGUST, SUNDAY 19, 1888
MONDAY 20.

TUESDAY 21.
First letter from Sister
Annie rec’d this noon - telling
of her last illness & death of their
little Annette - she is more
cut down than seemed
possible for her - but no one
knows what a hurt comes
by death of loved ones until each
soul suffers for itself
entries.summaryText: Susan receives a letter from her sister Annie informing her of the death of their little Annette and how it has affected her.

entries.fullText:
In Memoriam.
Mrs. D. R. Anthony, accompanied by
D. R. Anthony, jr., arrived Sunday even-
ing with the remains of little Annette, and
yesterday morning they were consigned to
their final resting place in Mount Muncie.
The services being private, none but the
immediate family and a few intimate
friends were present; Dr. T. C. Tupper
officiating.
A number of beautiful floral offerings
from former playmates were silent but
affectionate tokens of the love they bore
the little on who has been called hence
entries.summaryText: Mrs. D. R. Anthony arrives with the remains of little Annette and they were consigned to their final resting place in Mount Muncie. Dr. T. C. Tupper officiated the private services. Floral offerings were given by former playmates.

entries.fullText:
This day rounds out
64 years for Brother D.R.
and 18 years for D.R. Jr -
who is now 2 inches taller
than his father- Sister
Annie was 44. a few days
ealier - the 14th I think --
entries.summaryText: Brother D.R., D.R. Jr, and Sister Annie celebrate their birthdays.

entries.fullText:
Brother D.R. & family went
to Excelsior Springs for a week
and oh how they will think
if only little Annette were here
how she would enjoy!!
entries.summaryText: Brother D.R. and family go on vacation to Excelsior Springs without Annette.

entries.fullText:
Fredrick Douglas dined
with us - Isaac Willis had
invited him - then his son
Henry was ill all night, & his
wife not equal to the strain
entries.summaryText: Fredrick Douglas dines with the author and Isaac Willis, but Henry falls ill.

entries.fullText:
Sunday 26.
Monday 27.
Sister May, Lucy E. H.
Louise & self went
to Wyoming - Mrs. B. F.
Avery's
entries.summaryText: Sister May, Lucy E. H., Louise and Susan B. Anthony went to Wyoming to visit Mrs. B. F. Avery on August 25, 1888.

entries.fullText: SEPTEMBER, SUNDAY 30, 1888
OCTOBER, MONDAY 1.
TUESDAY 2.
OCTOBER, WEDNESDAY 3, 1888.
THURSDAY 4
FRIDAY 5

entries.dateText:
OCTOBER, SATURDAY 6, 1888.
SUNDAY 7
Left Philadelphia at
4 P.M.
MONDAY 8
entries.fullText:
OCTOBER, SATURDAY 6, 1888.
SUNDAY 7
Left Philadelphia at
4 P.M.
MONDAY 8
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Philadelphia on Sunday, October 7th at 4 P.M.

entries.fullText:
OCTOBER, TUESDAY 9, 1888
Left Washington - 7.40
P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Washington on Tuesday, October 9th at 7:40 P.M.

entries.fullText:
WEDNESDAY 10.
THURSDAY 11.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not write anything of note on Wednesday, October 10th or Thursday, October 11th.

entries.fullText:
Columbus - Ohio - $50
Centennial Celebration -
Mrs. Henrietta L. Monroe -
Ms Henderson's, 65 Parsons Ave
entries.summaryText: Attended Centennial Celebration in Columbus, Ohio with Mrs. Henrietta L. Monroe and Ms Henderson.

entries.fullText:
Left Columbus at 9 A.M.
Reached Indianapolis - 2 P.M.
at Mrs May Wright Sewall's
entries.summaryText: Traveled from Columbus to Indianapolis and stayed at Mrs May Wright Sewall's.

entries.fullText: At Mrs Sewalls
entries.summaryText: Stayed at Mrs Sewalls in Indianapolis.

entries.fullText:
Left Indianapolis at
12.21 - arrived
Chicago at 6 P.M.
Slept at Cousin Albert &
Melissa Dickinsons
entries.summaryText: Traveled from Indianapolis to Chicago and stayed at Cousin Albert and Melissa Dickinsons.

entries.fullText:
Took 10 P.M. train
for Ames Iowa
entries.summaryText: Took a train to Ames Iowa.

entries.fullText:
Reached Ames - & the
house of Mrs - at noon -
who gave a nice reception
to the friends of
Suffrage this eve'g -
entries.summaryText: Reached Ames and attended a reception hosted by Mrs for friends of Suffrage.

entries.fullText: Speech this ev'g - at the Iowa State W. S. A. Con -
entries.summaryText: Speech at the Iowa State W. S. A. Con

entries.fullText: The state annual W.S.A. Con -
entries.summaryText: The state annual W.S.A. Con

entries.fullText: Left Ames - Iowa at 12.50 and reached Omaha at 6. p.m. & the house of Maggie Stanton Lawrence - at 706 North 19th Street - to see my friend Elizabeth Cady Stanton - talked over her getting out the call for the 21st Washington Convention -
entries.summaryText: Visited Maggie Stanton in Lawrence, talked with Elizabeth Cady Stanton about the 21st Washington Convention

entries.fullText: At 706 - North 19th St - Omaha - Mail with Mrs Stanton - and farly to get the call written.
entries.summaryText: Received mail with Mrs Stanton and worked on the call

entries.fullText: Left Omaha at 9 A.M. and reached Leavenworth Kansas at 4. P.M. - on the east side & crossed over on the old Ferry boat -
entries.summaryText: Traveled from Omaha to Leavenworth Kansas

entries.fullText: In Leavenworth - Mattie mass & holy concert this A.M. Mrs. Nellie Orbison of Lockport Ny. and - Maude's Boston school wrote - this evening - I slept with Susie B. in the nursery
entries.summaryText: Attended mass and holy concert, received letters from Mrs. Nellie Orbison and Maude, slept in the nursery with Susie B.

entries.fullText:
In Leavenworth-- Arthur
came this A.M.
Sallie Halderman
married this ev'g--
Maude, Susie, Davis
& Orbison went--D.R.
Annie & self visited at home
Susie B. & self slept at the Snyders this night
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Leavenworth, including the arrival of Arthur, the marriage of Sallie Halderman, and a visit to the Snyders.

entries.fullText:
In Leavenworth
Annie took me
out to Mt. Morris--Susie
took chrysanthemums,
tried [?] roses--sister
Hannah's train is [?]
up some as the little [?]
sister Annie & self slept in nursery bed--& Susie B.
on lounge at the foot of the bed--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Leavenworth, including a trip to Mt. Morris with Annie and Susie, and sleeping arrangements for the night.

entries.fullText:
In Leavenworth--
Arthur & Mother
nurse & baby boy left this
A.M.--for St. Louis--so only
Nellie Orbison visitor was left--she
slept with Maude in her room & I with Susie B in nursery--
Dr. A. went to Chetopa to
speak in campaign--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her visit to Leavenworth, including the departure of Arthur and Mother, and a visit from Nellie Orbison.

entries.fullText:
Left Leavenworth at 7.40
A.M. and reached
Fort Scott at 1.00--
Brother D.R. arrived
at 2.00--& spoke in
Fort Scott this evening--Mary L,
Merritt & I all went to hear him
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her travel to Fort Scott and hearing her brother D.R. speak.

entries.fullText:
D.R., Merritt & self were
together this day--all
rest are left--save sister
May--we drove out
to the sulphur well--&
D.R. took the 1.30 train
for home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about spending time with D.R. and visiting the sulphur well before he left on the train.

entries.fullText:
at Fort Scott
Had disagreeable rough
throat & cough
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about having a rough throat and cough while in Fort Scott.

entries.fullText:
Tried a sulphur
bath - and drank
the water twice,
or more a day right
along -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony tries a sulphur bath and drinks the water at Fort Scott.

entries.fullText:
Little Julie Baker taken
ill with typhoid fever to day -
in Aaron's & Maggies new
home - Orange - California
entries.summaryText: Julie Baker falls ill with typhoid fever in Orange, California.

entries.fullText:
Mrs & Bessie Randolph
gave a large reception
to me - May S. & Merritt
went with me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a reception hosted by Mrs. and Bessie Randolph with May S. and Merritt.

entries.fullText:
Left brother Merritts at 1.15
P.M. - reached Leavenworth
at 6.20 P.M - Found
all well -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Merritt's and arrives in Leavenworth.

entries.fullText:
At Leavenworth -
Getting a priestly
black Henrietta cloth
dress made - by Miss
L. Parsons -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Leavenworth and is getting a black Henrietta cloth dress made by Miss L. Parsons.

entries.fullText: In Leavenworth
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Leavenworth.

entries.fullText: In Leavenworth
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Leavenworth.

entries.fullText: In Leavenworth
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Leavenworth.

entries.fullText: In Leavenworth
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Leavenworth.

entries.fullText:
[*Miss Maggie - all these days
& weeks nursing her little Gabe through
typhoid fever - in their California
home at Orange -*]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Leavenworth and mentions Miss Maggie who is nursing her little Gabe through typhoid fever in their California home at Orange.

entries.fullText: Maude & Miss Orbison at the Fort - Capt. Marshalls
entries.summaryText: Maude & Miss Orbison visited the Fort with Capt. Marshalls.

entries.fullText: Left Leavenworth at 8. A.M. Santa Fe R.R. - Susie B. drove me to station - at Topeka called on Judge Adams - his daughter took me to her Capital office - met Mr Hudson & talked over situation - reached Emporia at 4.50 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Traveled from Leavenworth to Emporia, stopping in Topeka to meet with Judge Adams and his daughter, and met with Mr. Hudson to discuss the situation.

entries.fullText: Kansas State W.S. Con. Emporia - guest of Senator Kellog - Mrs K. is daughter of Rev D.P. Mitchell - formerly of Leavenworth - 1865
entries.summaryText: Attended the Kansas State W.S. Con. in Emporia as a guest of Senator Kellog and met with Mrs. K., daughter of Rev D.P. Mitchell.

entries.fullText: Emporia - Kansas W.S.A. Annual mtg stopped with the news election state attorney - Mr Kellogg -
entries.summaryText: Attended the Kansas W.S.A. Annual meeting in Emporia and stopped to hear the news of the state attorney election with Mr. Kellogg.

entries.fullText: Emporia - Annual mtg in Congregational Church was pledged to speak to the Leavenworth High school pupils Friday at 2 P.M but had telegraph Susie B. it was impossible for me to get back there in time.
entries.summaryText: Attended the Annual meeting in Emporia and was pledged to speak to the Leavenworth High school pupils but had to cancel due to travel issues.

entries.fullText: Pres Taylor invited me to talk to his 500 state normal students - took train at 11.20 - reached Leavenworth at 6. P.M -
entries.summaryText: Was invited by Pres Taylor to talk to his 500 state normal students and took a train to Leavenworth, arriving at 6 P.M.

entries.fullText:
Miss L. Parsons
finished flannel
wrapper - & black
- dress - fit nicely -

Left Leavenworth at
2 P.M. - brother D. R.
went - Kansas City with me -
D.R. Jr. on train going home -
Took Chicago & Santa Fe Train
at 6.20 - & brother D. R.
went back to L , Susie B met
Depot with us - held dog Arny by the collar to
keep her from rushing under the cars
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Leavenworth to Kansas City with her brother and meets Susie B at the train station.

entries.fullText:
Rockford - Ill -- State Con.
Miss Kittie G. Waugh [-take]
entertained by - Mrs R. W. Emerson -
reached R. at 2. the " very are
cultured people - elegant
reception this evg - Rachel
Foster came to the. reception -
she seemed happier than words
can tell
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a State Convention in Rockford, Illinois and is entertained by Mrs. R. W. Emerson and meets Rachel Foster at a reception.

entries.fullText:
Nice audience - Mrs May
E. Holmes presiding -
made an hours speech in
evg- on men willing when women
want to vote - splendid
audience at 25 cts admission
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gives a speech on women's suffrage to a nice audience in an event presided by Mrs. May E. Holmes.

entries.fullText:
Attended con A.M. &
P.M. and took 3. O'clock
train back to Chicago
- Found cousin Susan
Hoxier Richardson &
husband visiting the
Dickinsons -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a convention in the morning and afternoon and returns to Chicago to find her cousin Susan Hoxier Richardson and her husband visiting the Dickinsons.

entries.fullText:
May Wright Sewall & Frances
Willard and self spent day & ev'g
to .10 Oclock - talking national
Council - Mrs S. & I slept &
breakfasted at Hotel -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day and evening with May Wright Sewall and Frances Willard at the Southern Hotel in Chicago, discussing the national council. They slept and breakfasted at the hotel.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. S. & self called at the
Sherman House- Rachel came
& dined with Mrs. Mallan - then
went to the Dickinsons & visited
with Melissa & cousin Susan
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. S. visited the Sherman House, dined with Rachel and Mrs. Mallan, and then visited Melissa and cousin Susan at the Dickinsons.

entries.fullText:
At Chicago Ill - Albert &
Melissa Dickinsons-
Walton Flats - Cor [?] & [?]
26 years ago to night at 11. O clock
O clock our dear Father left us.
Cousin Susan Hoxie & husband & self
went to Riverside to dine with
cousin Hannah Ragles -- Albert
drove down [ma???] ?ot able to go

Found cousin Fannie at home
early ev'g - glad to find her here
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent time with Albert and Melissa Dickinsons at Walton Flats, and then went to Riverside to dine with cousin Hannah Ragles. She also visited cousin Fannie at home in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Galna- Ill- 18.50
Ms May E. Holmes,
Took 9 A. M train from Chicago
reached Galna - 2 P.M - Dr Angie
Newman of Nebraka on train -
had good chat had nice
audience -
niece Maggie taken down with Typhoid
fever this day
also ???y Kng -,
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a train from Chicago to Galna, where she had a good chat with Dr. Angie Newman and a nice audience. She learned that her niece Maggie had taken ill with typhoid fever, as well as someone named ???y Kng.

entries.fullText:
C. N., [Lockin???]
[B?da] [?] 2,
Ms Holmes worked [?]
took dinner & reached [?] at 9.20
- soon [aud?ei?]- Mr L.
shut blind in the war-
left B. at 2.30. A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked and had dinner with Ms Holmes, and then left B. at 2:30 AM after Mr. L shut the blind in the war.

entries.fullText:
Reached Monmouth at
5.30- slept till 8, breakfast
at 8.20 train at 9.40 -- st
Louis 5.20 p.m. -- Found
Mr & Mrs Minen [??y] such
& had a very pleasant &
hospitable talk over
the fundamentals of our
movement --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reached Monmouth and had breakfast before taking a train to St. Louis, where she had a pleasant and hospitable talk with Mr. & Mrs. Minen [??y] such about the fundamentals of their movement.

entries.fullText:
At Mrs. Virginia L. Minors
St. Louis - Mo. - & Mr. & Mrs R.
& self took Thanksgiving dinner
with Arthur & Mattie this day -
entries.summaryText: Thanksgiving dinner with friends in St. Louis.

entries.fullText:
Jefferson City - Mo. $60. & Lords
L.C. Lohman -
Left St Louis at 9 A.M. - at Jeff.
City found letter from M Lohman that
said Slayton had sent no Lithos or
Posters - he had not advertised me -
so went to Sedalia - Raiser Hotel - &
staid till 10.40 - then took train for
Hannibal - & sat up all night
entries.summaryText: Traveling from St. Louis to Hannibal, encountered issues with advertising.

entries.fullText:
Pittsfield - Ill -
N.A. Harvey
arrived at new Pitsfield Hotel
at 7 A.M. - the Pike County
Teachers Institute in Session - had
splendid audience & made a
fairly good speech - Send out
the ballot -
entries.summaryText: Attended the Pike County Teachers Institute and gave a speech.

entries.fullText:
Left Pittsfield at 8.20 -
jogged along westward all
day - waiting an hour at
Moberly - arriving Kansas City at
7.30 - taking Mo. Pacific train
at 8.20 - passing by Leavenworth
at 9.20 - wanting to stop
but feared to worry Mrs. Colby
entries.summaryText: Traveling from Pittsfield to Kansas City, passed by Leavenworth.

entries.fullText:
Omaha - Neb. - State W. S. A.
guest of Mrs Cornish - at
1202 - South 10th - arrived at
7 A.M - learn that Maggie
Stanton's husband is very ill
Splendid reception at the Paxton
entries.summaryText: Arrived in Omaha, guest of Mrs. Cornish, learned of Maggie Stanton's husband's illness.

entries.cityOrState:
Neb. State Con
(niece Maggie McLean Bakers
second week of typhoid fever)
entries.fullText:
Lunched with Mrs.
Stanton & her Maggie - Mr
Lawrence ill - & going to California
with his father & mother
entries.summaryText: Lunch with Mrs. Stanton and Maggie, Mr. Lawrence is ill and going to California with his parents.

entries.fullText:
Took breakfast with the
Kimballs - reached Fremont
at 7. P.M. - guest of
Mrs Nye -
entries.summaryText: Breakfast with Kimballs and guest of Mrs Nye in Fremont.

entries.fullText:
Left Fremont at 9. A.M.
reached Sioux City - 3.30 P.M.
Had nice visit with Frank & Ella
Dix - Mosher - they both & their
two babies well -
entries.summaryText: Visited Frank, Ella Dix, and Mosher in Sioux City.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Caroline A. Ingham
left Sioux City at. 9 A.M. on Ill Central
east - then north - then east again -
reaching Algona at 9.05 - and the
platform at 9.15 - audience been
held by speeches & songs 1 hour & a quarter
made good speech - till near 11.
entries.summaryText: Made a speech in Algona after traveling from Sioux City with Mrs Caroline A. Ingham.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Geo P. Sevhez - -
Left A at 9. reached
Fayette at 6.20 - made a
poor speech - stopped hotel
Took train at 11.45 - after lecture
waited at Calmar till 3. A.M.
entries.summaryText: Made a poor speech in Fayette and waited in Calmar until 3 AM.

entries.fullText:
Took sleeper to Savannah Ill -
then breakfast on Dining car - and
reached Chicago at 1.20 -
found them just at dinner
at the Dickinsons - Cousin
Charles Anthony - Uncle Alron's son
was at the D's with his only son,
William - whom the Doctors had
entries.summaryText: Traveled to Chicago and had dinner with the Dickinsons, Charles Anthony, Uncle Alron's son, and William.

entries.fullText:
declared had Cancer in the left
shoulder joint bone -

He was taken to the
Presbyterian Hospital this day
& on tomorrow - Tuesday the whole
arm & shoulder were taken off -
Cousin Dr. Fannie Dule - saw
the whole butchery - and the Surgeon
"if there is any discretion in the room
this is the time to use it" -
entries.summaryText: Visited the Presbyterian Hospital where a man had his arm and shoulder amputated due to cancer.

entries.fullText:
Joliet, Ill - 40
Lawyer - Lettie L. Burlingame
guest of Mrs Addie Syme & Mr George
J. Monroe - & the mother Mrs. Syme
- Left Chicago 8.40 A.M. & arrived J. 11.50 -
Had splendid audience over 400 - in the
Universalist Church - she that was
Bridget Carr - that used to work for
sister Mary - was present & came
up to speak to me - Had to call for Mother
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks to an audience of over 400 in Joliet, Illinois and is visited by Bridget Carr.

entries.fullText:
Attended the Con. morning
session & told them best plans -
took train at 3.20 P.M. and slept
at Union Hotel - Galesburg -
Weather clear crisp & lovely -
more like Spring or early Autumn
than December -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a morning session and shares her plans before traveling to Galesburg.

entries.fullText:
Augusta, Ill. 40 -
Left. Galesburg at 10. arrived A. at 12.30
Mr Edwin Artz. - stopped at the
Commercial Hotel - Rev D.G.
Bradford - Pres. minister - introduced
me - he's President army relief corps
- coughed a good deal - It
looks as if colds were were going
to hinder us speaking - this is the second this Fall
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Augusta, Illinois and is introduced by Rev D.G. Bradford.

entries.fullText:
Genoa - Ill - 25 - J.E. Stott
Left Augusta at 6. A.M. arrived
Chicago at 2.30 and stopped in
Depot till 4. - Cousin Hannah
& Doyles happened in - so had a
good visit - had good audience
- arriving at 6. - but cold broke
me down into a cough - almost
aug breath
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Genoa, Illinois and has a good visit with Cousin Hannah and Doyles.

entries.fullText:
Left Genoa at 8. A.M. reached
Chicago at 10.20 - and went direct
to Dickinsons - rainy & muddy -
the first in two months -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Chicago and visits the Dickinsons.

entries.fullText:
In Chicago, at the Dickinsons
Molton Hats - Con. Clark & lend spent
Cold, seems better - but it is
a close pinch -
[*Niece
Maggie
3d week
of Typhoid*]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time in Chicago with the Dickinsons and notes her niece's third week of typhoid fever.

entries.fullText:
In Chicago - Still under
the weather too much to start
east - so Telegraphed
Aurora - Impossible to lecture East &c -
Dr Julia Holmes Smith of
521 - Dearborn Ave came to see me
& retold my starting out -
East --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Chicago and too sick to travel east. She telegraphed Aurora and Dr. Julia Holmes Smith visited her.

entries.fullText:
Aurora - N.Y. - $50
Elbert G Hubbard -
- Had mustard on back
& chest - & nearly blistered bath
- worried for the morning
of my audiences - which couldn't
be notified -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Aurora and received $50 from Elbert G Hubbard. She is worried about her upcoming lectures.

entries.fullText:
Dr. Julia H. Smith - still commanding
quiet - Cousin
Melissa - is too feeble to
have an added care -
still she does so much
for me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Dr. Julia H. Smith and her cousin Melissa.

entries.fullText:
Left Chicago at 5.3. on
Limited - Lake Shore & Southern
Michigan train - Dr Fannie took me
to Depot - got through night very
fairly -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Chicago on a train with Dr Fannie.

entries.fullText:
Reached - Rochester N.Y. home
at 11. A.M - found sister
Mary expecting me - felt none
the worse for journey -
- Didn't go over to no 19. to
meals - but sister Mary
brought them over -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Rochester, NY and her sister Mary brings her meals.

entries.fullText:
At Home - Feeling
better - and hoping
the worst is over -
went over to dinner - &
wrote several letters - &
read up the basket
ful waiting here
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home and feeling better. She writes letters and reads.

entries.fullText:
At Home - & better -
Sister Mary went to Church
a Rev. Fish Jr. preached -
they have no settled minister yet -
- Miss Morton & Miss Ballantyne
called in P.M. - Mary Hallowell
spent the evening - had a nice visit
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary went to Church and Miss Morton & Miss Ballantyne called in P.M.

entries.fullText:
At home - Weather
soft & bright - slushy streets -
Mary down town - wrote letters
Lucy E, Maude, brother D.R. &c -
sent some p.k.ffs to Lucy E Louise &
Cousin Jessie -
entries.summaryText: Mary wrote letters and sent some p.k.ffs to Lucy E Louise & Cousin Jessie

entries.fullText:
At Home - some better
but too little almost to appreciate
Had Roast Turkey at no 19
with only regular family - the
two widows - Granger & Canan -
Mrs Armstrong, Mrs Dudly - sister Mary
& self - The day warm like
spring - snow melted & []
very muddy -
entries.summaryText: Had Roast Turkey at no 19 with only regular family

entries.fullText:
At Home - 17 Madison st -
Rochester - N.Y
A letter from Geo. L. Baker
Orange - Cal written Dec. 17. posted
from Leavenworth the 23rd - tells of
niece Maggie being very ill with
Typhoid Fever - Gulie & Tomy King
had had it - but now convalescing -
the 18th would be Maggies 21st day
of the fever.
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Geo. L. Baker about niece Maggie being very ill with Typhoid Fever

entries.fullText:
So as no
telegram of death has come -
we are full of hope for the best.
What a sad fortune is brother
Aaron's - 1st little Anthony, then Ann Eliza,
then Tomy King, then sister Gulie and
now to have to give it his last
darlg' Maggie would be no added
sume - indeed -
entries.summaryText: No telegram of death has come and reflecting on brother Aaron's sad fortune

entries.fullText:
Gladstone is 79 to day - so he
was born Dec. 29. 1809 - 3 years
before brother A.M. McLean
entries.summaryText: Gladstone's birthday

entries.fullText:
This is sister Guelma's & Aaron's
76th birthday - being them born Dec. 31.
1812 - day rainy & dark - feeling
more like myself - sister Mary has a dress
maker - Miss Crittenden here to day - making
[?] a gray cloth travell'g dress -
- In the olden days - this once used
to be brother Aaron's birth day & the
new years dinner - often -
entries.summaryText: Celebrating Guelma and Aaron's birthday
